illnessScript.summary: Abdominal pain in primary care: identify urgent surgical, vascular, and gynecological causes early while managing common self-limiting conditions safely.

mustNotMiss.whyDangerous: Delay increases risk of perforation, sepsis, and emergency surgery.
mustNotMiss.escalationConcern: Urgent same-day surgical assessment if progressive right iliac fossa pain or peritonism.

mustNotMiss.whyDangerous: Rupture can cause catastrophic intra-abdominal hemorrhage.
mustNotMiss.escalationConcern: Immediate emergency referral for possible ectopic pregnancy symptoms.

mustNotMiss.escalationConcern: Urgent ED referral for colicky pain, vomiting, distension, and obstipation.

prompts.label: Focused exam summary
prompts.significance: Supports narrowing differential and immediate safety decisions.

whenHelpful.rationale: Helps detect physiological instability during consultation.
Used when findings will change immediate management.
Reserve for diagnostic uncertainty or higher risk presentations.

selfCare: Provide symptom-control advice tailored to current severity.
Confirm patient understands red-flag escalation instructions.
followUpLogic: Escalate immediately if red flags emerge during observation.
Arrange same-day reassessment if pain is worsening or diagnosis is uncertain.
Provide clear return precautions and documented safety-net advice.

returnAdvice: Seek urgent care for worsening constant pain, fainting, or persistent vomiting.
Seek urgent care for blood in vomit or stool, black stool, or new fever.
Seek urgent care for new severe pain in pregnancy or possible pregnancy.
escalationTriggers: Severe worsening pain with guarding or rebound tenderness
Persistent vomiting or inability to tolerate fluids
Positive pregnancy test with unilateral lower abdominal pain
